items.title: Sonoma County opens local psychiatric health facility
items.summary: The Sonoma County Healing Center, a new psychiatric health facility approved by the Sonoma County Board of Supervisors in May 2020, officially opened today. The county-owned facility, located at 7440 Los Guilicos Road in Santa Rosa will provide short-term treatment to individuals experiencing mental health issues.

items.title: Weekly Roundup for Jan. 21, 2022
items.summary: Today’s digest provides helpful and important updates on the following: 1) Update on the situation in local schools; 2) How to get rapid tests, N-95 masks for free; 3) What to do if you contract COVID-19; 4) Vaccine & testing clinics in Sonoma County; 5) Rental assistance, mortgage relief available; 6) COVID-19 community resources & support; and 7) Other news items from County of Sonoma

items.title: Financial literacy and financial well-being are important to overall health.
items.summary: Learn more about the link between financial literacy and overall health and wellness, and access resources for financial wellness and emergency financial support.
tags: Sonoma County Maternal Child and Adolescent Health

items.title: Medical Director Services for Juvenile Institutions and Valley of the Moon Children's Home
items.summary: The Department is requesting proposals from clinical healthcare organizations that maintain a focus on pediatric and adolescent care, but also encompass specialty care such as OBGYN, Medication Assisted Therapy (MAT) Services for Opiate Use Disorder and psychiatric services, to provide Medical Director Services and potentially mid-level services at Juvenile Hall, Probation Camp, and VOMCH.

items.summary: Today’s digest provides helpful and important updates on the following: 1) Latest virtual community update on COVID-19 available for viewing; 2) Upgrade your mask, health officials urge; 3) What to do if you contract COVID-19; 4) Vaccine & testing opportunities in Sonoma County; 5) Mortgage relief available for some homeowners; 6) COVID-19 community resources & support; 7) Other news items from County of Sonoma

items.title: Birth Defects. Learn more about what causes, and how to prevent, Birth Defects.
items.summary: Not all birth defects are preventable, but healthy lifestyle choices lower the risk of birth defects. A combination of Exposures and Risk Factors contribute to raising or reducing the chances of birth defects. Learn more about lowering the risks of birth defects:
tags: Sonoma County Maternal Child and Adolescent Health

items.title: Sonoma County Health Officer issues appeal for residents to voluntarily stay home; restricts large gatherings
items.summary: Due to the rapid rise of COVID cases surging through the community, Sonoma County Health Officer Dr. Sundari Mase today issued an appeal to residents to stay home as much as possible for the next 30 days and limit interactions with those outside of their immediate household.

items.summary: Today’s digest provides helpful and important updates on the following: 1) Upgrade your mask, health officials urge; 2) What to do if you contract COVID-19; 3) Pfizer booster authorized for 12- to 15-year-olds; 4) Reporting health order violations on face coverings; 5) New state rules for visitors to hospitals, long-term care settings; 6) Vaccine & testing opportunities in Sonoma County; 7) COVID-19 community resources & support; 8) Other news items from County of Sonoma

items.title: Covid updates: Vaccination during pregnancy talking points, new booster requirements and isolations guidelines.
items.summary: Local, State and CDC Covid updates for the perinatal community. New MCH vaccination in pregnancy talking points, the difference between antigen and PCR tests. Will Covid become endemic? Is Covid causing developmental delays in kids?

items.title: Sonoma County health officials issue cold weather warning
items.summary: The County of Sonoma is issuing a cold weather warning in response to the National Weather Service’s prediction of possible freezing overnight temperatures on Friday, Dec. 31 through Monday, Jan. 3. Temperatures are expected to drop to the upper 20s and 30s for most areas. Officials recommend that residents limit time outdoors, as serious medical conditions including hypothermia and frostbite can develop with prolonged cold weather exposure.

items.title: Request for Proposals for Hepatitis C Testing Services
items.summary: The County of Sonoma is pleased to invite you to respond to a Request for Proposals for Hepatitis C Testing Services.

items.title: Sonoma County rescinds face mask exemption for fully vaccinated groups
items.summary: Sonoma County today joined four other Bay Area counties in rescinding exemptions to local public health orders that allowed stable groups of fully vaccinated people to remove their masks indoors in some workplaces, gyms, churches and other public settings.

items.title: Sonoma County issues COVID-19 guidance for New Year’s gatherings
items.summary: People planning to travel and attend gatherings on the New Year’s Eve holiday should take steps to protect themselves and their families from COVID-19, Sonoma County Health Officer Dr. Sundari Mase, said today.

items.title: Sonoma County urges employers to require proof of COVID-19 booster shot or at least twice-weekly testing
items.summary: Employers should immediately require all workers to get a booster dose of the COVID-19 vaccine, if eligible for one, or get tested at least twice weekly for COVID under new guidelines issued today by Sonoma County Health Officer Dr. Sundari Mase.
